questions.question: What is an implication?
questions.explanation: Implication: logical if-then. Form: 'if p then q'. Antecedent: p (condition). Consequent: q (result). Truth: false only when p true, q false. Logic: fundamental reasoning form. Examples: all conditional statements.

questions.question: When is implication false?
questions.answer: When antecedent true and consequent false
questions.explanation: False case: p true, q false (TF). All other cases: true. Examples: 'If rains then wet' false when rains but not wet. Verification: truth table shows. Importance: defining condition.

questions.question: What is the antecedent?
questions.explanation: Antecedent: p in pq. Role: condition/hypothesis. Position: before arrow. Importance: determines consequence. False antecedent: implication always true (vacuously).

questions.question: What is the consequent?
questions.explanation: Consequent: q in pq. Role: conclusion/result. Position: after arrow. Importance: what follows from condition. True consequent: implication always true.

questions.question: What is the converse?
questions.explanation: Converse: opposite direction. Original: pq. Converse: qp. Different: not logically equivalent. Example: 'If wet then rains' (false sometimes). Importance: different meaning. Warning: don't confuse.

questions.question: What is the inverse?
questions.explanation: Inverse: negate antecedent and consequent. Original: pq. Inverse: pq. Different: not equivalent to original. Example: 'If not rains then not wet'. Relationship: inverse and converse equivalent to each other.

questions.question: What is the contrapositive?
questions.explanation: Contrapositive: negate and reverse both parts. Original: pq. Contrapositive: qp. Equivalent: logically identical. Example: 'If not wet then not rains'. Usage: sometimes easier to prove. Importance: always equivalent.

questions.question: What is transitivity?
questions.answer: If pq and qr then pr
questions.explanation: Transitivity: chaining implications. From two implications: pq and qr. Conclusion: pr. Validity: sound principle. Example: 'If study then pass, if pass then graduate'. Application: logical chains.

questions.question: What is modus ponens?
questions.answer: From pq and p, conclude q
questions.explanation: Rule: if pq true and p true, then q true. Validity: sound inference. Use: deductive reasoning. Example: 'If rains then wet; it rains; therefore wet'. Importance: fundamental reasoning rule.

questions.question: What is modus tollens?
questions.answer: From pq and q, conclude p
questions.explanation: Rule: if pq true and q false, then p false. Validity: sound inference. Use: deductive reasoning. Example: 'If rains then wet; not wet; therefore not rains'. Importance: fundamental reasoning rule.
